Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research: Exploring Statistical Analysis Methodologies in Selected EMC/SI Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Electromagnetic Compatibility (CEMC) comprised of the Missouri University of Science and Technology (MUST) and the University of Houston (UH). Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 11-570. The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research.

The goal of the project is to explore and develop statistical analysis methodologies for practical EMC and Signal Integrity applications. The proposed research will be focused on two areas: 1) charactering effects of geometry/material variations, manufacturing tolerances, and process variations on high-speed signal channel performance; and, 2) characterizing random noise sources through nearfield scanning. Various methodologies will be investigated through modeling and measurements, and the gained insights can be used to develop effective design tools for specific practical engineering applications in the next step. The high-speed design community has neither systematic experimental procedures nor simulation-based tools for addressing random effects in complex real-world problems, which are critical when the industry moves ahead to the next generation of designs. The proposed study will close this gap by developing and improving general statistical analysis methodologies for real-world EMC and signal integrity applications.

The successful completion of the project will result in a deep understanding of various statistical analysis methodologies for high-speed designs, which can provide useful insights and guideline for engineering CAD tool development. The outcome of the project can help the nation to maintain its competitive advantages in high tech industry. The next generation of electronic, computer, and communication systems will benefit when more accurate modeling and measurement techniques to address random effects become available. The knowledge gained in this project can inspire similar ideas and approaches in other engineering fields to incorporate statistical methodologies. The proposed innovative research will be effectively integrated into education to transfer the developed technologies into the minds and hands of the next generation workforce. Research findings and results will be disseminated through the IUCRC CEMC to the center members, and through conferences, publications, and websites to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The direct outcome of the proposed research is the fundamental knowledge on high-speed channel modeling, via design, and near-field scan. The proposed statistical analysis methods are successfully applied to improve the quality and robustness of high-speed channel designs and the accuracy of measurement.

The non-intrusive stochastic collocation (SC) method and the intrusive stochastic Galerkin (SG) method have been formulated based on the polynomial chaos (PC) theory. Both are implemented in MATLAB. The methodologies we have learned are ready to be applied to other topics as well, although the project mainly focuses on high-speed channel modeling. Currently, the obtained methodologies are used to optimize BGA pin map and to build generic models for high-speed channels.

A conclusion is given that the SC method is relatively easier to be realized than the SG method while keeping the same accuracy. The SC method is independent of the solver. It doesn’t require any knowledge of the solver. It is just based on the post processing of the obtained samples out of the solver. Thus, the SC method is simple and straightforward. It can always be applied. On the other hand, the SG method requires the user to have sufficient knowledge of the algorithm behind the solver. Then, the user can modify the solver based on his application to include the statistical information. Sometimes even if the algorithm is well known by the user, there is just no way to apply the SG method. Thus in the future applications, it is recommended to use the SC method.

The SC method is also compared with the DoE method. Each method has its advantages and disadvantages. Both methods can always be applied as long as the deterministic solver is available. The two methods differ in the way selecting the sampling points and the algorithm conducting the post-processing. The accuracy and efficiency of the two methods are also different. And both are case dependent. But generally, it is more efficient to use the DoE method and more accurate to use the SC method.

The theory and applications of the DoE method is studied. The DoE method proves itself an efficient way to maximize the information of interest. However, the method may be lack of accuracy sometimes, though highly efficient. If a rough estimation is required, DoE method is a nice alternative. The knowledge of applying DoE methods facilitates our other projects on generic models for high-speed channels and BGA pin map optimization.

Through the comparison of different statistical analysis methods, we have gained understanding and insights for developing effective engineering tools in the next step.

The proposed phase-resolved near-field scan technique is useful for the real-world applications because electronic products often contain multiple active circuits producing noise-like signals. The noise sources can be separated by selecting a reference probe site deliberately during the scan. Important VNA settings for such a test have been discussed in our published paper. The far-field pattern caused by each source can be calculated accordingly from the scanned near-field data. Moreover, the scanned data also allow the emission sources to be located using the ESM algorithm.

The successful completion of the statistical analysis methods fills in the gap for technology transfer. High-speed channels require deliberate designs to satisfy some restrict requirements. Nevertheless, no matter how well the designs behave, they may suffer from the non-ideal effects during the manufacturing process, which degrades the technology transfer. Our proposed method takes these variations into account even during the design process. In such a way, the design is more robust. Deliberate designs can be manufactured successfully.

All in all, the research is fruitful. We successfully completed the objectives that we listed. And beyond that, the obtained knowledge from this study is currently facilitating our other projects.
